text:
in the intersection of
innovation and government? Sure, so I'll go back to--

as Paul said, I was a-- became a venture
capitalist in 1999, which, for those of you who
researched ancient history

in the venture community,
that was the tail end of one of the biggest bubbles
in the industry. So the internet
bubble in the '90s

was a great time for venture
capitalists to make money, to raise large funds,
and to hire new people. So it was a very easy
time to get a job,

and that's how I was able to
break into the business was to get a job. But the problem with getting
a job at the end of a bubble

is, as a venture
capitalist, there's a long lag time between the
investments that you make

and when they come to fruition. And so it was really
hard to keep your job if you got a job in 1999 in
the venture capital industry.

I was fortunate enough
to be able to do that because the
industry crashed in 2001. And all the initial
investments I did sort of

looked pretty bad at that point. So I went back to
my roots, which is I grew up in
Washington DC with my dad

working for the US government. And so I thought to myself,
hey, the US government spends a lot of money
on technology products

and services. I never see them as an
interesting vertical market for any of the startup
companies I look at. If I could help figure out how
to help these companies sell

into the US government, that
could help differentiate me as an investor in a much more
difficult time in this industry

to differentiate yourself
and be successful. And so I surveyed some of
the CEOs in my portfolio.

One of them Chris Darby
raised his hand and said, yeah, I'd like to figure out
how to sell the US government. And so Chris and I went
to DC a couple of times

and met with people and
tried to help his company Sarvega sell products
into the US government. Along the way, we met In-Q-Tel,
which was really getting off

the ground at that point. And In-Q-Tel was going
to invest in Sarvega, the company Chris was
running when we sold it

to Intel corporation. And, about a year later,
In-Q-Tel called us up.

They were looking
for a new CEO in DC. And they were interested in
talking to Chris about that.

But they were also looking
for a managing general partner in Menlo Park. And they were interested in
talking to me about that.

So that's how I made the move. And, to me, at the end of it was an opportunity to
bring both parts of my life

together, the part of life
growing up in DC with not just my dad but a lot of my
friends, parents working for the government, and then
the part of my life since 1992

being out here in Silicon Valley
working with startup companies in some form or another.

Alan. Oh, good. I teach with Steve Blank. And one of his many great
lines is, what do you

call a failed entrepreneur? And he says, experienced. So you've had your
challenges or early days

that you had a failed
startup, I think, in '94. But then you had some success. Can you describe some of
your earlier struggles and what you learned and
how you overcame them?

Sure, so I like to joke I worked
for three startup companies. And one went out of
business, one got bought,

and one went public. So that's the whole spectrum. Only one of those three
things can happen. And it happened in that order.

So, hopefully, I got
better at picking which startup companies to go to. But, when I graduated
from the GSB--

I know there are some GSB
students in the audience. But, when I graduated GSB in

and sort of the
whole vibe of going to work for a startup company,
it wasn't really there. Everyone went to investment
banking or consulting or firms

like Procter and Gamble
or 3M or places like that. And it was kind of unheard
of-- or not unheard of.

But there were maybe 10 of us
that graduated without a job and said we wanted to go
work for a startup company. And we figured that out.

So it was much more
unusual back then. And the first startup company
I went to had a great idea that I'm sure many of
you will resonate with,

which is, we built a modem that
plugged into a Sega Genesis or Super Nintendo machine
that allowed you to play

video games over the phone lines
against people in other homes. It was the first
time someone could play a video game against
someone who wasn't sitting

next to you on the couch. So a great idea,
$1 billion idea. But we were too early.

And, ultimately, that
company went out of business after being there for two years.

And what happens when a startup
company goes out of business is you get laid off. So, all of a sudden, there I
was, having gone to this school that you guys don't like
me to talk about back east,

and my parents had
scrimped and saved on a government-employee salary
in order to pay for my tuition there.

And I had saved a lot of
money working after college to pay for Stanford Business
School, which was not cheap

then. I'm sure it's not cheap now. And, all of sudden,
I found myself walking into the San Mateo
County Unemployment office

and getting an
unemployment check. And that was kind of
a grim moment for me

because you start to
think like, geez, I thought I was kind of hot shit. I went to Harvard and
Stanford Business School.

And here I am without a job
and no money to pay my rent unless I get this
unemployment check.

And that was kind of
a dark day for me. And it is sort of
almost a rite of passage now to go through a failure.

But, back then, it wasn't really
what I was expecting there. And I made it through, in part,
because of the group of GSB

classmates I had
that all decided to go through startup
companies and decided, hey, we support each other.

And it did become a badge
of honor after a while. And the next company
I went to didn't care.

And they employed me. And, like I said,
that got bought. And so we made a
little money on that. And then the next
one was E*TRADE. And that went public, and I
made a little money on that.

So now it sounds
like a great story. But, back then, it
was definitely--

when I think of the
down moments in my life, walking into that unemployment
office was definitely one of them.

It feels like every person in
Silicon Valley who's successful also has that story of
the one that got away.

What was that for you? So, when I was there in between
that first and second startup

company, dealing with
where my life was at, my college roommate who had
started out on the venture

capital side and then decided
he wanted to start a company asked me to be his cofounder.

And I just wasn't ready
to take that risk again of doing a startup.

And we were probably looking
at a year without salary. And I just couldn't
pull that off.

So I passed on the
startup company. That company became
a company called [? Kona ?] Communications. It was the first
company to use email

as a medium to provide
customer service and support. So all these companies
were, all of a sudden,

getting email because
email just emerged in 1994 and '95 as a medium. And they didn't know
what to do with that

and how to provide customer
service to customers that were emailing them. And so he built the application
that did it, went public.

He made tens of millions
of dollars off of that. And so that's probably the
one that got away for me.

But everything all
works out in the end. I tell lots of people because
the venture capital business,

you miss deals. And I love to tell young venture
capitalists that work for me, it's not about the
deals you don't do.

Don't worry about that. Everyone's going
to miss the deal. It's about the deals you do do. Just make sure some number
of the deals you do are good,

and everything will be fine. And don't worry about
the ones that you miss. So maybe a little more
on how you eventually got into venture capital.

You had some
interesting experiences. But you lived at ground
zero there in Menlo at the base of Sand Hill. But how did you get into it?

So, summer of 1993, I'm at
Stanford Business School. I'd worked for a
government consulting

firm in between undergrad
and business school and come out to California. Thought I was going to be a
two-year California vacation.

I upgraded for weather
from my undergraduate place and was having a great time.

But I decided I would try
the startup world out. And so I interned or a startup
company in the glamorous world

of network management software,
a company called Net Labs. And they had venture
capitalists on the board

And so I reported to the venture
capitalists on the summer project that I did. And I got to see what
they did as a job.

And I thought that
was pretty cool. So I met with each of
those in my second year of business school
and said, hey, I kind of like what you did.

How do I become a
venture capitalist? And they said
look, Steve, you're kind of a smart,
hardworking, good guy.

But there's a lot of smart
and hardworking people that want to get in
the venture business. Why don't you go out and
get operating experience in an area you think we'll
be interested in investing

five years from now? Because that's the
best way to get a job in the venture industry. And so, in spring of my second
year of business school,

Mosaic, the first internet
browser, came out, and people started to discover
the idea of this thing called

the internet. And so, basically, I decided to
bet my five years, if you will,

of getting experience
in the internet, figuring that it would be the
hot area that people would want to be investing in when
I'd be experienced enough

and qualified enough to get a
job in the venture business. The short story is
that's what I did.

Obviously, the stories are
never quite as neat and easy as that sounds. But it's still I think a good
rule of thumb and a good sense

of, if you are interested
in getting into venture, go out and get
operating experience in an area you think
they'll be investing

in five years from now. It also helps you, when you
are a venture capitalist, working with entrepreneurs. If you talk about,
hey, I've been

there, trying to get the
first customer for a company. I've been there
trying to make payroll and not having cash
for four weeks.

I've been there when we've
had to lay people off. I've been there when
we've had to figure out how to scale because, all
of a sudden, our business

is taking off. It gives you a lot of
relevance to the entrepreneur as a board member that not
all venture capitalists have

if they've only worked
in investment banking or consulting and as a VC. So you've been with In-Q-Tel
for several years now.

Maybe we can start talking a
little bit more about In-Q-Tel. What exactly is In-Q-Tel? Sure, so In-Q-Tel is actually
an independent not for profit.

So we're a 501 (c) (3). And we were created
by CIA in 1999 to bridge the gap between
the innovation occurring

in the then 10,000 plus
venture-backed startup companies in the United States
and the technical challenges facing CIA at the time.

What they wanted
and what they had in their relationships
with large corporate R&D

groups like CR
Spark and Bell Labs was to both influence
product direction and try new technology
as it matured.

And they realized
that innovation had shifted in the United States
from those large corporate R&D labs to these startup companies.

And they didn't have
the ability either to influence product direction
or try it as it was emerging.

And so they created In-Q-Tel
to bridge that gap, as I said. We figured out
the best way to do

that was to act as
an investor first and foremost because
acting an investor

is gives you entrance
into the club. And you start to hang out with
people from General Catalyst and other firms like that.

And they treat you as a peer. And they are much more, quite
frankly, intellectually honest with you about
what the company is

and what the technology
does than if they perceive you to be just
a vendor, generally with the entrepreneurs. Secondly, though,
we had to figure out

a way to influence
product direction and purchase the product so that
the government employees could

try it because
what companies want is they want purchase orders. And they get funded,
as I think most of you

know or are learning, in And so, in order for them
to raise their next round of funding, they have to
demonstrate tangible progress

to their investors. The best way to demonstrate
tangible progress is purchase orders. And the government traditionally
didn't make a purchase order

decision less than 12 months. In fact, it typically
takes 24, 36, 48 months. And so that's why startup
companies traditionally

ignored the government. So we created this mechanism
that's called a work program. It's a contract between
In-Q-Tel and the company.

We invest to create that
equity relationship. We get an observer seat
to the board of trustees.

We give companies
some NRE dollars, NonRecurring Engineering
dollars to influence the product

direction. And then we purchase enough
product to do a pilot. In-Q-Tel as a customer,
we sign the PO.

We have the right to deploy
a pilot at CIA, NSA, one of the other agencies
because we've grown over time to where
we now work with nine

different government agencies. If that pilot goes
well, we then work with the procurement people such
that they then procure directly

As a 501 (c) (3)
non-for-profit, we measure ourselves
first and foremost by the number of
pilots we generate and the number of
adoptions we generate,

as well as the qualitative
impact score that we get from them about how
important those pilots or adoptions were.

Any proceeds we generate
from our investing just get reinvested into
our model so that now, today, we provide somewhere
between 35% to 40%

of our funding from
proceeds we've generated from previous transactions. And 60% to 65% of our funding
comes from the agencies

that we work with. So it's a discount
to the taxpayer in terms of what we do.

Over time, we've
evolved, as I said, to where we now work with CIA,
NSA, NRO, NGA, DIA, Customs and Border Patrol, FBI,
ONR, Office of Naval

Research, CENTCOM, and DHS. And then we also have
an international fund

that we get money from the
CIA, the Brits, and the Aussies to invest international. And we also now invest this
to-- the most recent thing

that has changed for us. As the primary mission of
the defense and intelligence

community has shifted from
global war on terrorism to nation-state competition
with China and Russia,

they've realized that
commercial technology is an important strategic
lever in that competition. And so CIA and others
are looking at us

and saying, so what's
China doing with Huawei? How are they using
Beijing genomics to project power and
influence, geopolitical events

around the world. What about TikTok? And so we're now investing not
just to deliver capabilities.

But we're also realizing that,
by sitting on the boards of 150 companies around the world at
the cutting edge of emerging

technology, we have a unique
perspective on what China's doing, how they're trying to
influence standards bodies out

there, how they're
trying to subsidize certain technologies to be
adopted by Africa and South

America in particular. And so we're providing
insights back to our customers

about that. So I like to say,
yesterday, we invested just to deliver capabilities. Today, we invest to deliver
capabilities and insights

as well. Steve, government-facing
companies face a lot of challenges. Startups, Palantir,
Anduril, and a lot of people

like to point out for
example, those two companies, what do they have in common? They got billionaire cofounders. But they also got
help from In-Q-Tel.

And In-Q-Tel is famously
helpful with Palantir. But what's In-Q-Tel's role
in those government-facing

companies, like Anduril,
Palantir, or others? Look, I think we help in
a lot of different ways. But our fundamental
value proposition is we got both Palantir and
Anduril their first government

customer through that
work program mechanism that I just described. And that's so important
to startup companies

when they're first getting
started is, how do I get that first customer? How do I make that customer
successful and referenceable so other customers will buy?

So Palantir, we
got involved early. I think we were one of the first
investors outside the Peter Thiel collection of funds
that invested in them.

And we walked them into
CIA, DIA, NGA, three different government agencies.

And we ultimately
got pilots from them. And those pilots led to
adoptions as I talked about. So, when Trae Stevens
who was here, I think,

a couple of weeks ago,
talked to you guys, had the idea at Founders
Fund to start Anduril,

he came down and
talked to us and said-- this was even before they
incorporated the company. And so he said, we're
starting another company here.

I'm sure he gave you his
little schtick here-- I think it's great. At the time two of the five
highest-value private companies

in the world were
Palantir and SpaceX. But number three on that
list of private companies

that were selling
to the government-- was like number 2,500
in terms of value. And so he was like,
I want to start

the next Palantir and SpaceX. And it was Anduril,
and I want In-Q-Tel to be involved from
the very beginning here

and run the same playbook that
we ran with Palantir to get us to the first customer. And we did with Anduril at CBP.

So that's really our
sweet spot of what I think is bringing value is
getting that first customer

contract because it's such
a leap for the government to contract with a startup
company that has no government

business. And it's these government--
these startups that are focusing on government need
some sort of market validation,

as Paul alluded to in his
opening comments here, for their investors that what
they're doing makes sense.

And so an investment, a
work program from In-Q-Tel gives them that validation. We get them to their first
customer quicker than they

otherwise would've. We throw a lot of
bodies at that pilot to make it as
successful as possible.

And then, once it's successful
and they get that adoption, then the company
is more on its own to go out and sell to
other government customers

as both Palantir and Anduril
and a number of other companies in our portfolio have done. And, Steve, there's also
a number of more, call it,

dual-use companies that
In-Q-Tel has supported, invested in, and helped
get off the ground. I'm thinking specifically like
MongoDB, Cloudera, FireEye,

Databricks. Maybe can you share
a little bit more about what was In-Q-Tel's
role in at least one

of those companies? Sure, that's really
actually our sweet spot. There aren't that
many-- although, it's

increasing every day. There aren't that
many startup companies that are venture backed that
are government-first companies.

Palantir, back when it
was the first company-- Jo will remember. There were a lot of
venture capitalists

that just wouldn't look
at Palantir because it was selling to the government. And they're like,
we don't understand how to sell to the government.

And you look at that first
set of investors Palantir got, it was not the
traditional VC community. Fast forward 10 years,
when Trae started Anduril,

he was able to get brand-name,
tier-one firms like General Catalyst to come in
and invest because they

were comfortable with it. But the bread and
butter of what we do is actually dual-use technology.

So these are typically
companies that have started out to build products to
serve commercial customers

and have concluded either that
the government's too difficult a market for them to go after.

Or they aren't even
aware that there is a market within
the government for their technologies. And so we're pretty good at
identifying those companies,

going in, and de-frictionizing
the process for them to think about, hey,
what if I do a work program with In-Q-Tel.

I'll get a couple of customers. I can build a federal
sales vertical. And then, when some
of these companies went public that you talked
about FireEye, Mongo,

Cloudera-- eventually, I think we all
expect Databricks to go public.

Those companies had a
vertical public sector, vertical market that was
generating 20% to 25%

of their revenues. That's meaningful to
a private company. And they couldn't-- they
probably need us more than

Anduril needed us. By the time Trae started
Anduril, he knew pretty-- he knew a lot of things about
how to sell to the government.

And some of those other
government-first companies are the same way. But the companies
that we just listed,

they really knew a
lot less about selling to the government. They had to be convinced. Their investors
and board members had to be convinced that, hey,
it's worth our time and energy

to do that. But if you want to do
big-data analytics, you want to use companies
like Databricks and things

like that. If you want to do
great cyber stuff, you want to do use FireEye
and other things like that.

It's great for the
government agencies to access those technologies. We shamelessly plug a course
called Hacking for Defense

here if you're a Stanford
student and want to take it. But we adopted Steve Blank's
business model canvas

to what we call a mission
model canvas because there's differences when you're dealing
with the government, the DOD

or any government agency. Success is never
measured in-- not in revenue like the
commercial sector,

but an impact in
mission achievement. And, importantly, the
person buying the product isn't the person using it.

I mean, it's just different
working with the government. How does In-Q-Tel approach
the government as a customer?

So I like to say, the person
who cares about your product sits here. The person who has
budget sits here.

The person who has purchasing
authority sits here. So, in order to get a deal
done with a government agency,

you have to do this sort
of weird triangulation that is much more complex and
less straightforward than when

you're trying to sell to
Morgan Stanley or Walmart or you pick the brand
name, a commercial company.

The way we work with these
agencies is, when we ask them-- or they decide they
want to work with us,

they have to do three things. First is they have
to give us money. We need money to invest.

Second thing they have to
do is give us a problem set. This is a list of what
problems they want

us to make investments against. That, to us, is just
a starting point in the conversation with
them about what they really want because, oftentimes,
they'll say we want X.

Then we'll bring them a
company that does X, and they'll say, now that
I see it live and can touch it and feel it, I
realize I need X plus Y.

So we'll go back and find a
company that does X plus Y. So it's an iterative process
to figure out what they want.

And then the third thing
we do is we ask them to create an interface center. And the government
being the government,

they create an acronym along
with that interface center called the In-Q-Tel
Interface Center, which became the QIC, Q-I-C.

And
these are full-time government employees whose job it is to
represent the problem set back to us. And, when we bring companies
in identify the end users that

want to participate
in the work program, but then, once we do
the pilot, they're also identifying how we're
going to do procurement. So there's procurement expertise
in the interface as well.

And, like I said, we're
doing all this work to de-frictionize the process to
set up the procurement process

such that if the end user
says, thumbs up, like what this pilot does, they're
ready to contract directly

with the portfolio company. And that's what you have
to do in the government is you have to find an end
user who's your champion.

You have to find and identify
a place in the government that has the budget.

And these budgets are committed
one, two, three years out as you know. So you have to
figure out, how am I going to get this
funded in the meantime

before the budget frees up? And then you have
to figure out, what is the contract vehicle,
the purchasing authority that you're going to use
to tie this all together

to get a deal done? So it is complex. We have built a-- like lot of venture
firms, we built a set

of resources around
the investing efforts that we do to help
our companies. We call it the Government
Platform Accelerator, GPA.

And so we then have resources
available to our entrepreneurs that we invest in to
say, hey, all right,

now you've got your
pilot customer. You're thinking
about, hey, how do I build a federal sales team? Who do I interview?

How do I find them? How do I evaluate them? How do I count them? These are things
that the big primes,

like the back of their hand. But if you're a startup
entrepreneur who's only worked at Google or
Facebook or Cisco or Intel,

you've never really
done this before, we have resources to help you think
about that, figure that out.

And so we try and educate
our companies so that, when they have success, they're
ready to take advantage of that

and build an even
bigger business and deliver more impact to
our government agencies. And what are some
of the problems that's in sectors you're
focused on right now?

Yeah, so big-data analytics has
been a very active theme for us

for a long time. That today is about AI. And generative AI is
certainly becoming

more and more of a part of it. Cybersecurity has been
another consistent area for us

to invest in. But what people don't
realize is about 45% of the investing we do
is actually in hardware.

So we're actually one of
the more prolific hardware investors out there. So we invest in
microelectronics companies. We got a co-investment with
Paul at General Catalyst.

It's a complete moonshot deal
to disrupt the microelectronics

manufacturing world
and help reset it in a way that's more
favorable to the US interest than it currently is today.

We did-- to Joe's point, we made
our first commercial satellite

investment in a company that
was just spin out of Stanford. It was a group of students
out of Stanford called Skybox. And I think we probably made
that investment in 2009,

so well before commercial
satellites were a real thing. And, in fact, I
remember showing it

to this guy that was Air
Force and NRO and CIA.

And he was the point person
for the community at that time and working with SpaceX. And we showed him this
group of Stanford students

that wanted to
build a miniature, a "smaller than cube
size" satellite.

And he walks out of the
meeting and just goes, oh, I remember when
I was young and naive and didn't know
what I didn't know.

And we're like, no,
you were missing this. This is how these
companies get built. And, six years later,
Google bought them for a healthy sum of money.

And we had the intelligence
community, finally, sort of figuring out that,
hey, just because we build

these exquisite classified
satellites in the sky, it doesn't mean
we can't leverage

a lot of commercial technology
for other use cases in a--

I'm running on a
little bit here, but I just wanted to hit
one last point on this. If you paid attention to
the conflict in Ukraine,

first of all, we're very proud
that we have over 30 portfolio companies contributing
technology to that effort.

But one of the first ways we
contribute-- our portfolio contributed value was before
the conflict even started.

For the first time, the
US intelligence community and the State Department and
the foreign service community in general started to share
intelligence publicly, saying,

Russia's saying they're
not going to invade, but we can show you. Their troops are here. They're pre-positioning
people over here.

We shared information collected
by satellites with allies and with the public.

And we did so because
it'd been collected by commercial
satellite companies. Previously, the
intelligence community

never wanted to
share intelligence because then you had to--
it would expose classified mechanisms and means that it
might have been collected by.

And it was a lot easier to
share commercial technology. So it was a real
impact story for us. One of the things
we're most proud of

is the way we've helped
the community really adopt commercial satellite
as an important mechanism

in collection. So, Steve, this is a class
called Silicon Valley in the government. So this is a self-selected
group of students

who have an interest in
working at the intersection of government and innovation. You mentioned that national
security challenges

are shifting, terrorism to
great power competition. Well, what are the opportunities
now for these students here

to get involved at
the intersection of government innovation? Oh, I think there's
lots of opportunities. The US government,
the intelligence

and defense committee, I think
it was like a big tanker. It's really hard to turn. But, once you start
to turn it, it's

sort of inevitable
that just keep turning. And so that's where we
are I think in this space.

For a long time, the
government didn't want to abandon or stop relying
on its core set of primes.

And it wanted to keep just
working with those same set of companies.

But they finally figured
out that, for certain areas of technology, they're
still world-class partners,

but other sets of
technology, they're not. And they're never
going to get there. If you want to be world
class at autonomy, if you want to be
world class at AI,

if you want to be
world class at cyber, if you want to be
world class at sensor platforms and
collection, you have

to engage in the
commercial startup world in order to get the
best and brightest.

What the commercial
and the Fortune 100 figured out-- and,
quite frankly, in the 2000-to-2010 time
frame, it took the government

until now to figure it out. But they figured it out now. And they're inevitably shifting
an increasing percentage

of spend each year to that

MVP, Minimally Viable
Product process. But the common mistake, I think,
entrepreneurs make sometimes

is they think they know
what the market wants. And they just start to

When I did come out here
for Stanford Business School in 1992, I came out
a couple of weeks early

to get my place,
line up my roommates. And one of the things
I started doing was playing pickup basketball at
Roble, right around the corner

here, before school started. And, one day, it was a Friday
noon game, a friend of mine

who was going to be a
classmate and I were playing. And, afterwards,
these two guys who we'd been playing with
sort of sat with us,

and asked us what
we were doing, said we were about to start GSB. And they said, well,
we actually just graduated from the GSB
ourselves a couple of years ago.

And we still sneak out
from our jobs on Fridays to play basketball. So we said, that sounds
pretty good to us.

What advice would you give us? And they said two things. And I still think
it was actually

the most significant
two things I learned in my two years
of business school. So I could have saved
all that tuition and just played
basketball all the time.

But the first thing was
don't be competitive with your classmates. A rising tide floats all ships.

And your classmates
from Stanford, whether it's undergrad or
one of the graduate schools that might be standing here are
going to be successful in life.

And that's going to
be an asset to you as you build your
career, the fact that you have relationships with people
that are being successful.

So if you're going
through that trade-off, do I want to study
a little bit more? Or do I want to go build a
deeper relationship with one

or more of my classmates? I would say skip the
studying and go hang out

with your classmates because
that will actually really help you in life and be
actually more rewarding than getting an A instead
of an A-minus in a class.

And the second thing they said
was, nobody ever pays you not to have an opinion. So one of the challenges that
people that are really smart, like all of you and go to really
smart schools like this, is you

want to find the right perfect
answer to every question. And you get in the
business world, and that's not nearly the case
of what the real life's all

about. It's sloppy. It's messy. It's dirty. You never have all
the data you need. You can never know for certain
what the right answer is.

And you have to have-- be
comfortable with having an opinion and making
a recommendation on imperfect information that
is some combination of analysis

but also a gut. And if you don't get
comfortable with that, you're never going to
be valuable to whatever

for sharing your time, your
insights, and just more about your work at In-Q-Tel. Great. Thank you, everybody.
